titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. Sunday. VII:45. Rose with a head-ache which was somewhat troublesome all the morning. Mrs Adams and Susan Buchanan rode out and paid several visits. I received one from Mr Bagot to enquire if I should probably have an answer to give him on the Mediation proposal so that he can send it by the Packet which is to sail from New-York next Saturday. I told him I thought I should be able to answer him the day after to-morrow, and asked him to call then at my Office at One; and he promised he would. He asked again about the proposition concerning the fisheries— I told him I feared we should not be ready for that, as we had not yet our answers from the interested parts of the Country. He said if we waited for their consent we should never be ready. We also had a long conversation upon the South American Affairs, concerning
which he said he had forgotten to tell me, that Lord Castlereagh had written to him that he should be enabled to make me a confidential communication upon the subject very shortly— I walked out an hour before dinner, and met Commodore Decatur— The weather has moderated since the Snow. We had a quiet Evening.

2. VII: Made a Memorandum of the answer to be given to Bagot; met Crawford at the President’s. Meeting of the Heads of departments at my Office; to consult together upon the Answers to be given to a call from a Committee of the House of Representatives. It was agreed after some discussion to meet again— Captain Davidson came and shewed me a Letter from Philadelphia, proving my apprehensions to have been founded to the fullest extent. J. B. Strong was at the Office; and W. S. Smith, and N. Pope, and Mr Buck, who has a Commission as Consul from Hamburg; but being a naturalized Citizen of the United States, wishes not to forfeit the rights of that character. I was detained at the Office till past four, and had yet no time for entering; and scarcely for reading, the Letters and despatches of the day— I left them in disorder upon my table, and many papers unsigned. I received a complaining Letter from Lucy Haüel— Dined at Dr Blake’s, with a company of sixteen, Mrs Blake, and her niece were the only Ladies at Table. The Senators Gaillard, Dickerson, Eppes, and G. W. Campbell, and the Members of the House of Representatives S. Smith, Bloomfield, Johnson of Kentucky, Nelson of Virginia, Strother, and Taylor of Indiana were of the Company. At eight O’Clock they were all gone. Mrs Adams called and took me up; and with Susan Buchanan and Mary Hellen we passed the Evening at Mr Bagot’s. It was a weekly and musical party, a company of about a hundred persons— A Mrs Knitel played on the Clarinett— Mrs Bagot performed on the Piano, and Mr ten Cate sung. I had conversation with several of the foreign Ministers and with Mr King. We came away soon after ten— My wife quite unwell the whole Evening.

3. VII: A Stormy day, with Snow, Hail, Sleet, and Rain. My wife was confined all day to her bed. I rode to the President’s, and home from the Office. Susan Buchanan went to Mrs Frye’s to enquire if she would go to the Ball this Evening at Dr Ewell’s— But Mrs Frye was unwell and could not go. Mr Bagot came to the Office at one, and I gave him the answer to the Spanish proposal for British Mediation, declining it; upon the grounds stated in the Memorandum which I drew up and read at the President’s yesterday. Bagot professed to be very well satisfied with the reasons which I gave him for our declining, the principal of which was the tendency which we apprehended it might have to excite ill-will and irritation in the minds of our People, against G. Britain herself. I touched as lightly as I could but very explicitly on the opinion against us so recently and repeatedly expressed by the British Government— He said that although we declined the Mediation, if there should occur any occasion upon which Great Britain could do any good, by throwing in a word; his Government would be happy to do it— He spoke of the execution of the Convention of 3. July 1815. and of the agreement relative to armaments on the lakes— Mr Van Ness, Commissioner under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent was at the Office, upon the Affairs of his Commission, and Mr Frye, relative to Administration upon Mr Johnson’s Estate— It was past five when I left the Office to come home— Quiet and busy Evening.

4. VII:Mrs Adams though better than yesterday, was still confined all this day to her chamber, and great part of the day to her bed. Mr N. Pope called this morning at my house to recommend the appointment of Captain O’Fallon as Register of a new Land Office at Boon’s Lick in the Missouri Territory. Pope is also full of Western Politics. At the President’s I met Crowninshield. The President was alarmed at a new Report, which he told me had been communicated to him by Mr Astor that the Amelia-Island adventurers intend to cruize in the track of our returning India ships to make prize of them— In the moment of agitation at this rumour, the President had written me a note concerning it, to be communicated to the Secretaries of War, and the Navy. I consider it, as a counterpart to the embargo at the Havanna. Yet every such report requires attention so long as it may be true.
At the Office Mr B. Irvine came; and I read to him the draft of instructions prepared for him. He said he understood that V. Pazos, the deputy from Amelia Island would be here to-day, or to-morrow, and another South-American, a Doctor Rossio. W. Lee came and Mr Dupont de Nemours called at the Office. Lee mentioned the fatal accident which has befallen Mr Astor’s Grandson Bentzon, a boy, eight or nine years of age with a son of Tennison the keeper of the Hotel, a youth of seventeen; both of whom went out to skate on the river, and have disappeared, supposed to have perished by falling through the ice— I dined and spent the Evening at Mr Middleton’s at Georgetown— The company at dinner were eighteen, and the Evening party about twenty more— Miss Bridon performed on the Piano, and Mr Middleton’s two daughters and Mr Ten Cate sung. Returning home, I took up Susan Buchanan and Mary Hellen, at Mr Frye’s where they had spent the day.

5. VII:Mr Walsh called at my house this morning, with a paper which he intends to publish concerning Amelia Island and which he lent me to read. He was afterwards at the Office, and borrowed a book and some newspapers. Mr S. H. Smith also came and introduced to me a Mr Fitzpatrick of New Jersey. At the President’s he complained of the numerous visitors who absorb all his time— At the Office Mr Holker called and occupied me a full hour with his claim against Daniel Parker. A Mr Hubbard from Ohio came concerning the project of forming a settlement on the Northwest Coast of America— It was past five when I left the Office, after an interview with Mr Calhoun at the War Office, to consult upon what is to be done, in consequence of the Reports of Aury’s future intentions. Mrs Adams is yet confined to her bed— Susan Buchanan went with Mr and Mrs Frye to an Evening party at Mr Weightman’s. G. Boyd was here, and told me of his project of obtaining the appointment of Consul at Smyrna. He said Mr Crawford had promised to speak to me about it— I gave him to understand it was out of the question— Mr Lee came, and introduced to me at the Office Mr Dupont de Nemours.

6. VII: At Noon I called at the Office of Mr Crawford at the Treasury, where there was a man who exhibited the model of a machine which he has invented for reaping, threshing and winnowing wheat all by a single operation, on the field. Genl. S. Smith was there; and enquiring after the papers relating to the remission of a debt to the United States due by a man named Kalekmann of Baltimore— They were at the President’s to be sent either to the State or Treasury Department, but have not been received at either. At the President’s and took his directions concerning several papers— He is preparing a Memorandum upon Onis’s last Note. At the Office I had a visit from Major Roberdeau. Mr O. Sullivan called also; the Consul at Mogadore, who is alarmed at a discovery which he has just made that the Consuls on the Coast of Barbary are prohibited from being concerned in commerce— I dined at Mr Clay’s with a company chiefly diplomatic, eighteen persons— Mrs Clay was not at table— They laughed at me about a blunder made in transmitting the copies of the papers of R. W. Meade’s case to the House of Representatives; among which papers by some accident, there was sent a remonstrance of Mr Erving to the Spanish Government against a blockade declared by Monlid in 1816— This paper being mixed with the others reported on Meade’s case has been printed with them, and has laid the foundation for another call of the House upon the President for more papers. Mrs. W. S. Smith spent the day here with Mrs Adams who is still confined to her bed.

7. VI:30. At half past ten this morning I attended a meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund, at the Committee Room of the Senate— I found Mr Crawford in the Senate chamber. At the Meeting, the board was full. Mr Gaillard, as President of the Senate, the Chief Justice, Marshall, Mr Crawford Secretary of the Treasury, and Mr Wirt, Attorney General, with myself, being present— The papers prepared by Mr Crawford for the annual Report were read and signed— Walking from the Capitol Hill with Mr Crawford, he told me he had heard that the Editor of the Washington City Gazette was one of the Clerks in my Office (Colvin) which led to some conversation upon the subject of that person; and R. Smith, his connection with whom has been very notorious— Crawford says that he knows, the intention of W. B. Giles, and W. C. Nicholas who forced R. Smith upon President Madison as Secretary of State, was to have Smith elected as the next President— The City Gazette at the Caucusing time, two years ago, was decidedly in favour of Crawford, against Monroe, and Colvin though then a Clerk in Monroe’s Office was said to have written many pieces against his election, which were published in the Gazette— just before the Treasury Office, we met Mr Clay, with Coll: Morris, the Marshall of New York. At the President’s I met Crowninshield— B. Irvine came, to the Office, and brought translated extracts from Letters of Carrera to him concerning South American Affairs. He told me that DrRocco, with Laborde were here; and Pazos from Amelia-Island, who had asked
him when and how he could transmit a memorial to the President, which would be in respectful language. I told him, it might at any time be sent to me, and I would immediately lay it before the President. I had sent for Dr Thornton, who came at one O’Clock— He had stated in a publication, signed a Columbian, in the National Intelligencer of 7. January last that M’Gregor had told him last June it was the intention of the Patriots to take the Floridas from Spain, and sell them to the United States for a Million and a half of dollars, and that he had communicated this to a member of the late Cabinet— I asked him who this was; he said, Mr Rush. I then asked him to give me in writing the substance of his Conversations with M’Gregor, and with Mr Rush; which he promised me he would; and he entered into some general statements of his connections with South American Patriots which has been of long standing, and in his view very important— Mr Silsbee called at the Office, about his claim; and Mr M. Morton, also a Representative from Massachusetts, about another claim of merchants at New-Bedford. It was almost six when I got home from the Office, to dinner— My wife was up, part of the day, and dined with us, the first time since Monday. Susan Buchanan went with Mrs Walsh, and spent the Eve at Mr Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister’s weekly party— I should have mentioned that Captain Davidson came to the Office yesterday, and informed me that my business at Philadelphia was transacted, at a great sacrifice; but not so great as I expected— By letting slip the precise moment upon which I had previously fixed for doing the business, I have made a heavy loss— It now remains to be seen whether by waiting longer, my loss would not have been greater.

8. VII: Engaged all the Morning in reading over the correspondence of the Extraordinary Mission of 1805, in Spain Pinckney, and Monroe with Cavallos, and making minutes of it— I did not get half through it. Attended at Church at the Representatives Hall. Heard Mr Hawley, from 2. Corinthians X.5. “Casting down imaginations, and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ”— With great objections against both the matter and Style of this Sermon, I thought it far superior to any other that I have heard since I have now been in Washington— A Psalm was read but not sung, and parts of the Morning prayer service were omitted; particularly the first Lesson. Notice was given after the Sermon, that the funeral of Tennison’sson, and Astor’s Grandson, Bentzon would be at 3. O’Clock this afternoon, with a recommendation to the Citizens to attend it— I returned the visits of Mr Harper and judge Johnson. I spoke to Harper about his concern with Mr Johnson’s affairs, and he gave me some information relating to them. Judge Johnson was in great perplexity to determine, whether the Executive or the Legislature or the Judiciary possessed the right of recognizing foreign Powers— He thought it was a concurrent authority. I came home, and found several Letters; one from Alr. Hanson concerning the Georgia Lands; and one from J. A. Smith of 20. December; announcing the arrival of R. Rush in the Franklin at Cowes. At three I went and attended the funeral of the two unfortunate boys; who were drowned in the Tyber— Their bodies were found yesterday. I found at the house where Mr Astor lodges a numerous assemblage of people, and in the house, Mr Clay, Mr Crowninshield, Commodore’s Rogers and Decatur, Mr J. J. Monroe, Genl. Dickenson, Messrs.Ten Cate, Greuhm and Sasse, and others. Mr Astor came to me and said that he had about two hours before received a letter, written for Mrs Bentzon, the child’s Mother, who had been informed of the Catastrophe— She insisted upon having the body sent to New-York that she might see it— He asked my advice, what to do— Without knowing that he had before consulted Mr Clay, I gave it as my opinion that the mother’s wish should be gratified— I found afterwards that Mr Clay had given the contrary opinion; which he again expressed very decidedly. There is certainly something in the construction of different minds that leads them to different conclusions, upon questions in which there can be no interested motive operating upon either— Mr Astor had had the child’s corpse carried to the burying ground with the other, but then took it back and concluded to send it to New-York. I took Mr Greuhm with me, in my Carriage to the burying ground near the Navy-Yard, and then home to dine
with us. Mr Everett came in after dinner, arrived yesterday from Boston, and spent the Evening with us. Cardelli was here this morning with a design for the Monument of the Baron de Kalb— The weather this day suddenly changed from very moderate to cold— Fahrenheit this Evening at 16.

9. VI:30. Rising half an hour before the Sun, I found Fahrenheit’s Thermometer at 2. At the President’s I told him of the conversation that I had with Dr Thornton on Saturday, at which he was somewhat indignant. There was a meeting of the Heads of Departments at my Office on the Subject of the Report to be made concerning the Salaries of the Clerk’s to be fixed by Law. After much discussion we agreed to meet again at two to-morrow. Mr Vicente Pazos came and delivered to me a sealed Letter for the President, and two large budgets of papers in Spanish— I asked him to have a translation of them made, but he said he could not, and that there were people in the Office who could translate them. I told him that they should be laid before the President, but not knowing what they contained, I could not say what would be done with them— Susan Buchanan passed the Evening abroad at Mr King’s, with her Cousin S. M’Kean.

10. VI:45. Fahrenheit again this morning at 2. And in the entry, within the house at 19. But the weather continuing clear, and the wind abating it moderated in the course of the day. At the President’s; he told me of Mr Poindexter’s intended motion in the House; to authorise the President to take possession of East Florida. Mr Trimble had called upon me, to speak of the paper respecting R. W. Meade’s case, which was withheld from the Communications to Congress— He said that Mr Sergeant would move to have his Resolution for reprizals referred to a select Committee, as there would probably not be a majority of the House for issuing reprizals immediately. I told him that he or the Committee should have the paper, confidentially, when they pleased. At my Office A. H. Everett called— He comes for Claimants on Account of French Spoliations before 1800— Then came Mr Hyde de Neuville— He had demanded an Audience of the President to present to him a Coll. Grouchy. The President said he must bring and present him at the Drawing Room; with which Mr De Neuville was not satisfied. He referred to the case of Lord Selkirk, and thought distinctions were made— General P. B. Porter came again about his accounts, and Mr Hulbard, about the projected settlement on Columbia river. The heads of Departments met again at my Office, about the Salaries of the Clerks— we made further progress, and are to have another Meeting to-morrow— I received a new Note from Onis— Everett gave me a Letter from Govr. Brooks to Mr Mason, upon Massachusetts Politics— There was a Ball this Evening at Mr T. Peter’s at Georgetown, to which we were invited; but we did not attend— Susan Buchanan went with Miss Sewall.

11. VII: At the President’s, I read to him a draft of part of an answer prepared to Onis’s Note, and which I propose to make a review of the whole controversy between the United States and Spain. The President approved what I had written, and directed me to continue it. At the Office there was again a Meeting of the Heads of the Departments, for arranging the Report concerning the Salary of the Clerks. Mr Everett, Mr Bulfinch with a son of Mr John Phillips of Boston, and Mr B. Irvine were also at the Office, where I was detained till past five— In the Evening Everett called and went with us to Mrs Monroe’s Drawing Room. A Message from the President to Congress concerning the furniture of his house, published this day in the Paper, produced a strange sensation at which the President was somewhat affected, and spoke to me about it. Ten Cate asked to have some conversation with me for which I appointed to-morrow at 2. O’Clock.

12. VI:Mr Walsh called upon me this morning, and shewed me the first draft of minutes which he has made, for pursuing the Newspaper discussion concerning the occupation of Amelia-Island— Mr N. Pope, and Mr Quarles also paid a morning visit. At the President’s, he requested me to see Dr Thornton, and express to him his opinions upon Thornton’s conduct in the affair of M’Gregor— At the Office, Mr B. Irvine came for his papers, but they were not quite ready. Mr Lawrence came about the account of J. Smith late Marshal of New-York, for the charge of aliens during the late War—a Question that I must settle. Mr Ten Cate came upon the Question concerning Tonnage duties upon Dutch Vessels— I told him that Congress would shortly receive a Message from the President recommending a Law for equalizing those duties. He said he would write me a Note upon the subject. I assured him of the desire of this Government, to shew every possible accommodation to the wishes of his and notwithstanding the failure of the late Negotiation of a commercial Treaty, we had an earnest wish to cultivate as much as possible the best Understanding with the Government of the Netherlands. He expressed himself
highly gratified with these Assurances which he said he would faithfully report to his Government. Mr and Mrs Boyd, Mr Frye, Mr. and Mrs W. S. Smith, Mrs Hellen, and Mr Everett dined with us. In the Evening we had Messrs: N. Pope, Trimble, Quarles, Robertson of Kentucky, and Scott— We had Cards, and I played a rubber at Whist— It was my wife’s birth day. She is 43. The Company left us between ten and eleven.

13. VI: Short visit at the President’s. At the Office I was crowded with visitors. Mr Bagot came to speak about the duties on English iron again. The papers have been laying a Month at the President’s. Yesterday a Message ready drawn was sent for him to sign, with copies of the papers for both houses— I told Bagot that they had probably been sent to Congress this day. He was afraid the subject would be overlooked— He also complained that a British Officer had been drafted for the militia, at Savannah. I told him, if he would send me a note, I would write concerning it to the Governor of Georgia. Everett came upon business of own; but finding me engaged will call again. Blake also gave explanations concerning his conduct as U.S. District Attorney, in the case of the late trials for Piracy at Boston. Mr Bassett came as Chairman of a Committee of the House of Representatives on the Beaumarchais’ claim, to examine papers— He said it had been reported at the Capitol that I had refused to see him, and sent him word I was engaged; but he had contradicted the Report— It shews that I have watchful enemies at the Capitol. Dr Thornton came; and I told him the President had directed me to tell him that he disapproved altogether of his having acted as an intermediate between M’Gregor, and Mr Rush; and also of his having advised M’Gregor to go to Mr Bagot— That he thought this interposition utterly incompatible with the duties of his Office, and should have given him to understand as much, if he had been informed of these transactions at the time when they occurred, which he was not. The Dr expressed great concern that the President, for whom he said he had the highest respect should have disapproved his conduct— He equivocated a little about his having advised M’Gregor to go to Mr Bagot, but ultimately did not deny the fact. He said he was afterwards sorry for it; and had distrusted M’Gregor, when he found he was gone to an English island— I referred him to his publication of 7. January, in the National Intelligencer, and the tone of censure upon the measures of the administration, relating to Amelia-Island—and implying a charge even of duplicity in the Government on that subject. He affected to consider that publication as referring only to the acts of the U.S. Naval Officers there, and pretended that he had thought they were acting without orders from the Government. I told him the President believed that he Thornton, had greatly misunderstood what Mr Rush said, in the conversation referred to; and that a copy of his Letter would be sent to Mr Rush with a request that he would communicate his recollections of it. He said he had no objection to that; but he was sure his statement was perfectly correct; for after drawing it up, he had shewn it to his Clerk Elliot, and asked him, if it was not exactly conformable to what he had told Elliott at the time; of what Mr Rush had said— That Elliott fully confirmed it; and if necessary was ready to attest to it upon Oath. The Dr. asked me if I thought the President would see him in person to explain to him the motives of his conduct. I told him I would mention this his wish to the President and take his directions concerning it— That I would report to the President the explanations that he had now given to me— That I should do it with a disposition friendly to him; but that in candour I ought to tell him that my impressions in regard to his conduct in this affair were the same as those of the President. B. Irvine came for his papers, but they were not ready. My time was so absorbed by these visitors at the Office, that it was past five when I left it— Genl: S. Smith had called on me with a Letter from G. Harrison to him, and a statement of Sarmiento’s Confidences at the Insurance Office, from Onis—Truth and lie, blended together. My wife went this evening with Susan Buchanan to a party at Mrs Cutts’s; where she was some time unwell, but recovered. I did not go.

14. VII:30. I reported to the President this Morning the substance of my yesterday’s Conversation with Dr Thornton, and particularly his request to see the President, to explain verbally his conduct to him in person. The President said he would not see him, nor have any conversation with him upon any thing, unless it
were Patents, and very little upon them— Mr B. Irvine came to the Office and took his Papers, for the agency to Venezuela. Mr Pleasonton came, and I gave him directions for the settlement of A. H. Everett’s account, and that of John Smith late Marshal of New-York. I had also some conversation with him upon my own accounts, and the principle upon which the Comptroller has objected against some of my charges, in which objections I told him I should not acquiesce— I dined at Mr Crowninshield’s in a company without Ladies. Messrs.Crawford and Calhoun. Commodore’s Rogers, Decatur and Porter. Captain Evans, Mr Silsbee & G. Blake were there— I came home at 8 O’Clock— Mrs. Adams and Susan Buchanan spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s.

15. VI:30. Attended with my wife and Mary Hellen, church at the House of Representatives. A Mr Keith who is to be settled at Georgetown, read prayers, and delivered extemporaneously a Sermon, from 2. Corinthians chap. 5. v. 19.20. “To wit, that God was in Christ, reconciling the world unto himself, not imputing their trespasses unto them; and hath committed unto us the word of reconciliation— Now then, we are ambassadors, for Christ, as though God did beseech you by us, we pray you in Christ’s stead, be ye reconciled to God.” It was Calvinism of the highest tone— He warned us that nothing but the brittle thread of our lives kept us from Hell. These are now episcopalian doctrines here. This man has talents and fluency. We paid visits to Mr and Mrs Ashmun, Miss Cushing and Miss Sumner— They are going home this week— Mr Ashmun who is a Senator from Massachusetts is to be absent the remainder of the Session. They declined coming to Mrs Adams’s Ball, as we understood on the point of etiquette that Senators do not pay the first visit to Heads of Departments— They come however and paid the visit yesterday. I also left a Card at Mr T. Ringgold’s lodgings— He is a member of the House of Representatives, and his wife and daughter have not visited mine, because I had not returned his visit. I walked home, and the remainder of the day was absorbed in the preparation of a reply to Onis. But the Evening was consumed by visits from A. H. Everett and J. Sergeant.

16. VI: After being engaged till noon, upon the draft of a Letter to Mr Onis, I attended at the Office without stopping at the Office— Tyler the writing master came with a subscription paper for an engraving of his copy of the Declaration of Independence with the fac-simile’s of the signatures. I subscribed. Captain Evans came with an old demand of 1809. for the expence of carrying Mr Fenwick, as a special Messenger to France and bringing him back— Mr J. M. Baker came to ask again for the consulate of Tunis, and brought a certificate in his favour from Captain Shaw. I was hunting up books and maps and correspondence upon the controversy with Spain, till five. Met Pleasonton as I was walking home; and spoke to him about Silsbee’s and Evans’s accounts. He says that no such allowance as that claimed by Evans has ever been made. My wife and Susan Buchanan spent the Evening at Mrs Bagot’s weekly party. I was deeply absorbed at home.

17. VI: At the President’s, met Mr Crowninshield. At my Office, Mr R. Kemper came and gave some account of Joshua Child, a man from whom I have received a very singular Letter and statement, much of which Kemper confirmed. Captain Evans came about his account for which I sent him to Pleasonton— Also Mr Lawrence— I sent Pleasonton authority to settle the accounts of the New-York Marshals by a compromise. I was hunting up Books and Maps of Louisiana without much success. Mrs Adams went with Susan Buchanan to a Ball at Mr Middleton’s— I was again occupied with the draft of a Note to Mr Onis until Midnight.

18. VII:Mr Walsh called at my house, and gave me a second Essay on Amelia-Island Affairs to read. I omitted calling at the President’s having nothing to communicate to him of importance. At the Office Mr Pleasonton called to speak of the Account charged by Captain Evans, and of the claim of Mr Silsbee— A fall of Snow which continued all the latter part of the day, preserved me from many visitors; I examined and selected the papers to be communicated to Congress, concerning Mr Pinkney’s Negotiation at Naples— And drafted a short Letter to the Governor of Georgia, upon an Application from Mr Bagot in behalf of a British Officer, drafted for the Militia at Savannah. Mrs Adams sent the Carriage for me, and I rode home with Susan Buchanan, who had spent the day with Mrs: Frye. The Librarian of Congress sent me a number of Books upon Louisiana, which were exceedingly wanted— I read nearly through this Evening, Tonti’s account of La Salle’s discoveries; and proceeded in my draft of a Note to Onis.

19. VII:Mr Walsh called again at my house, and I returned him his paper, with some remarks. At the President’s I met Mr Crowninshield— At the Office, A Mr A. Wheeler came with Letters and Certificates recommending him for the appointment of District Attorney in the Missouri Territory— Everett came, and I had much conversation with him concerning his views and prospects. J. S. Smith, Mr M’Culloh of Baltimore, and Mr Shepherd of N. Orleans, also Mr Silsbee with Mr Peabody of Salem, also paid visits at the Office— I examined part of the Correspondence
between C. Pinckney and the Spanish Government in 1802— Mrs Adams and Susan Buchanan, spent the day and dined at Mr Frye’s—Mrs Frye being very ill— I finished the draft of the Note to Onis, and began upon the supplementary matter—engaged till near one in the Morning.

20. VII:Mrs. Frye was at five this morning delivered of two boys—Seven Months children, not expected to live. Mrs. Adams went to her and remains with her this Night. I met G. W. Campbell at the President’s. Mr Anderson the Comptroller sent me a Letter stating that my Account as a Minister abroad was adjusted at the Treasury, and left a balance due from me of 3812 dollars 32 Cents. They have disallowed two charges, which make the real balance due to me of near 3000 dollars— On such Questions the Secretary of State is usually required to decide. But I cannot decide in my own case, and the President is averse to deciding it, so that for the present I am without remedy. I sent for Mr Pleasonton and had some Conversation with him upon it; but I am so much absorbed in public business that I cannot pay due attention to it now. The Vice-President arrived yesterday, and I visited him by card, and sent him a card of invitation for dinner to-morrow. After I came home this Evening I had a visit from our old fellow passenger, Major Lamb, who came on from New-York, with the Vice-President.

21. VII: My supplement to the draft of a Note to Onis engrossed the morning till past noon. At the Office I had visits from young Peabody and Mr Shepherd of New Orleans— The Vice-President, Mr Tompkins, called upon me this morning, and verbally accepted the invitation to dinner. I came home from my Office at four, and we had company to dinner— The Vice-President—Chief Justice Marshall, Judges Livingston, Johnson, Duval and Story, and Messrs:Berrien, Blake, Caldwell, Harper, Holmes, Hopkinson, Mills, Otis, Sergeant, W. Jones, & Winder. Judge Washington sent an apology last week, and judge Todd accepted but sent an excuse this day— The Company all went away immediately after dinner, and Mrs Adams went again to pass the Night at her Sister Frye’s— First Spring day.

22. VI: Rainy day. Confined to the house all the morning by the weather. Visit from Mr L. Harris. I was swallowed up by the drafting of my Note to Onis— Walk to the Seven Buildings and home before dinner. returning I met Mr R. G. Amory of Boston; who spoke to me in favour of W. Clark for the Consulate of Amsterdam— With the exception of my hours walk, and an hour at meals I was engaged unremittedly from six in the morning till midnight. Susan Buchanan went this Evening to Mr Frye’s, and neither she nor my wife came back this Night.

23. VII:Mr Walsh called with a third paper for the National Intelligencer— Rainy and Snowy day. I finished the draft of a Note to Onis. Met Mr Bagot going to the Capitol. He told me that he wished to present several English Gentlemen, to the President, for which I referred him to the Drawing room on Wednesday, and advised him to send before hand their names to Mr Monroe the Presidents brother which he promised he would. I found the President unwell, with a Cold and Cough. At the Office I found a Note from him mentioning that Aury’s deputy, Pazos had gone to him and penetrated to his Cabinet; he referred him to the Secretary of State— Dr Thornton came to the Office— I told him that I had reported to the President his explanations, and his request for a personal interview, which the President had declined. Also that his opinion had not altered of the impropriety of Thornton’s conduct. The Dr first affected to consider it as referring only to his publication of 7. January in the National Intelligencer; said he had been reading it over, and did not see there was anything in it offensive to the President, to whom it was very respectful— I told him the President’s disapprobation was of his transactions with M’Gregor, and then with Mr Rush; and his advising M’Gregor to go to Mr Bagot— He denied the fact— I told him I had it from Bagot himself— He then said he did not advise M’Gregor to go and see Bagot to talk with him about Florida, but as a Scotchman, because his family estates had lately been restored to him— And he had a great distrust of M’Gregor, as soon as he had heard he had talked with Bagot about
the Florida project— It was near six when I came home from the Office— Mrs Adams who is herself unwell remains at Mrs Frye’s. Captain Davidson came to the Office and gave me the papers concluding the transaction of the sale of my U.S. Bank Stock— There was a Ball at Georgetown this Evening instead of yesterday, for celebrating Washington’s Birth-day; we were invited to it and should have gone had my wife been well— In the Evening I made drafts of Instructions for William Taylor, to go as agent, to Cape Henry St. Domingo; and Jacob Lewis, as Agent at Port au Prince. They engaged me till Midnight.

24. VII:Mr Walsh sent this Morning for his Manuscript. At the President’s I met Crawford. There is to be a Cabinet Meeting about Pazos’s papers— While I was at the Office the President sent for me to call at his house again— It was to ask me to call to-morrow Morning for the selection and arrangement of the papers to be communicated to Congress respecting the South American Independents— At the Office, Mr Waite the printer, called and took leave; as did Dr Bates and A. Wheler, solicitors for Offices— Dined at Mr Walter Jones’s, with a company of 15 Gentlemen. Messrs.Clay, Mercer, Tucker, Ogden, Webster, Wheaton, Walsh, Blake and others were there— In the Evening I went to Mr Frye’s where my wife remains, with a swelling and inflammation of both her feet. Susan Buchanan also went there this day and stays there to Night. Mrs Hellen was there, and I took her to her home— Engaged till past Midnight reading papers— General P. B. Porter, the Commissioner, under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent, was at the Office, with Mr Adams the Astronomer of the Commission, who shewed me the drafts of their Surveys on the St. Lawrence river, the last Season. Mr J. L. Sullivan also came, and I had some Conversation with him concerning the Middlesex Canal.

25. VII: Going to the President’s this Morning, I met J. S. Smith with Mr Norbury Nicholas, who gave me a letter of introduction from his brother Wilson Cary Nicholas— At the Office Mr L. Harris came and had much Conversation with me upon the subject of the charges against him for misconduct in his Office as Consul at St. Petersburg. I told him what Rodde of Revel, had told me on the subject— He in substance admitted the facts. That bribes had been paid to Borel, and to Count Romanzoff’s Neutral Commission; but said he had no share in them, in his official capacity as Consul, but only as partner of the House of Cramer’s. He said he hoped for my Friendship, with the President— I told him that my personal disposition towards him was as friendly as could comport with my sense of public duty— The President would make up his opinion upon all the facts laid before him, upon the charges against him; and his answers— He would probably not ask my opinion— If he should I must in candour say, that I should under the present state of the Evidence say that facts charged were substantially supported, and that his explanations were not satisfactory— It appeared to me that if the complection of those transactions was different from what it appears, and justifiable, it could only be made to appear so, by an exhibition upon Oath of his Accounts with the house of the Cramer’s and a full explanation of every payment made to him, or charge to his credit in them— The same thing to be done with regard to his Accounts with all his Vice-Consuls— He said he would write to the Cramer’s, but his admission of all the material facts, makes that a useless expedient— Major Hawkins, agent to the Commissioners under the sixth and seventh Articles of the Treaty, was also this day at the Office— Almost immediately after dinner my wife was brought home from her Sister Frye’s, extremely ill— Dr Hunt came, and pronounced her complaint the Erisypelas. She has been five days and Nights at Frye’s, with her sister and the two dying children, in extreme agitation, and fatigues beyond the power of her Constitution to bear.

26. VII:Mrs Adams was better this morning; but was still confined all day to her bed. Mr Walsh called this morning, for his paper on the subject of Amelia-Island, which he had sent me last Evening to read. At the President’s I found Mr Crowninshield— G. Blake came to the Office, and brought me the paper containing twelve questions for the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States, brought up from the Circuit Court of Massachusetts on a Cause of capture by a South American privateer— The President read and returned to me, the draft of a Letter to Onis, with some alterations, and he advised me to shew it to the other Heads of Departments for their advice and remarks upon it. I took it, with the translation of Onis’s Notes to which it replies, to Mr Calhoun, who promised to read and return it to-morrow Morning. Mrs Boyd spent the Eve here with Mrs Adams. There was a Ball at the Marine Barracks to which Susan Buchanan was invited but did not go.

27. VII: Morning visit at my house from Mr Onis the Spanish Minister. He came to ask for an answer to his late Note concerning Don Diego Morphy, who while acting as Spanish Vice-Consul at New-Orleans was assaulted and beaten by a Frenchman whom the District Attorney there refuses to prosecute. Onis complained also that his own house had been of late repeatedly insulted—Windows broken—Lamps before the house broken; and one night a dead fowl, tied to the bell-rope at his door— This he said was a gross insult to his Sovereign and the Spanish Monarchy, importing that they were of no more consequence than a dead old hen— But if Spain was weak it was ungenerous to insult her weakness, which was owing to the unparalleled efforts she had made for the deliverance of all Europe from tyranny— I told him I hoped it was nothing more than the tricks of some mischievous boys— He said he had long been willing to think so, but was now convinced they were deliberate outrages of the South-Americans now here: he was sure that the people of the United States, and no person of this Country, had any agency in them. He also requested me, as the papers of our late Correspondence, were to be communicated to Congress, that he might previously see the translations of his Notes, made at my Office, that he might be satisfied of their correctness; an indulgence which Mr Monroe had granted him on a former occasion— I told him I should readily comply with his request, as I was very desirous the translations should be such as he himself would approve. I added that setting aside our official character I would tell him that I had directed the translations of his Notes to be compared with the pamphlet of Verus, and made conformable to it. This Verus is a pamphlet which he has lately published, containing the whole substance of his three long Notes to me; with some additional passages, insulting to the American Government, which he dared not put into them. He stammered something about Verus, not being a translation which he approved; but did not disavow the publication. I told him I should shortly send him a long and full reply to his Notes— That we regretted he had forced us again into this endless and useless discussion, but that my answer to him would be complete upon every point. This led us into a long conversation upon all the topics in which his principal refuge was to the uti possidetis of 1764. He left me, on Mr C. J. Ingersoll’s coming in, whose object was only a visit— Mr Bell, son of Mrs Bell, the late Mr Hellen’s Sister, came to ask for an Office in any of the departments. Not obtainable. At the President’s I met Mr Calhoun, who returned my draft of a Note to Mr Onis, proposing some erasures. He afterwards called at the Office, and made some further observations— The President had sent yesterday to the Office, to ask me to call as I should go home. But it escaped my Memory. He sent me this Morning a Note directing me to add a new paragraph to the Note to Onis concerning Amelia Island; promising to surrender it when the danger of its being reoccupied by adventurers shall cease. He told me this Morning, that he had given this direction in consequence of a Conversation yesterday with Mr Barbour of the Senate, who told him it would be necessary to satisfy the friends of the Administration, many of whom did not consider the occupation of the Island as warranted by the Law of 1811— Mr V. Pazos the man from Amelia-Island came to my Office to ask an answer to his memorial and papers from Aury. He asked me if Commodore Porter had spoken to me of him— He had not. He complained of being here at heavy expence— I told him that his Papers were under Consideration of the President, whose determination upon them, I would make known to him, as soon as possible— I took the draft of my Note to Mr Onis, to Mr Crawford for his perusal and remarks. Mr Correa the Portuguese Minister, spent an hour with me this Evening. He has just returned from a visit of ten days to Philadelphia— He says that the Negotiation between Spain and Portugal, at Paris will probably end in nothing. That Russia sides with Spain; but lately Great Britain sides with Portugal. And he added his belief that when the Russian Minister arrives here, we shall find him siding with Russia, also against us. My wife still continues confined to her bed.

28. VII: I made a draft of an additional paragraph, for the Note to Mr Onis, according to the President’s directions, and concerning Amelia-Island. At the President’s I found Mr Calhoun. On reading the new paragraph some alterations
of it were directed— Mr Crawford returned the draft of the Note to the Office without any remarks. I took it to Mr Crowninshield, who read and returned it to me, proposing several alterations and erasures which were accordingly made— I had at the Office, Mr Hyde de Neuville, and afterwards Mr R. King of the Senate. The Minister came to renew applications, for the restoration of a French Vessel taken by Aury and carried into Amelia-Island, where it now is; for a right of Frenchmen, to pay in Louisiana, no other or higher duties than the most favoured Nation; for a reduction of the duties on French wines— What was he to do? The French vessel was there, at Amelia; he was bound to take every measure for obtaining restitution. If the vessel was at sea, it could be retaken by a French frigate; but a French frigate could not come and take it at Amelia, while in possession of the troops of the United States— I told him that the process from the Courts of the United States did not extend to Amelia-Island: of course we could not try the question of French property or not, unless the vessel should come or be brought within our Jurisdiction— Well, but what was he to do? He had been offered to have the vessel given up, for a trifle; but that was not consistent with the dignity of the Crown— As to Aury, if they caught him they would hang him—for he was a subject of the King of France, and had thus been robbing French Subjects of their property— I told him that by refusing to receive restitution of the property, on a principle of dignity, he had been more scrupulous than Mr Onis who was very desirous of recovering a much larger property taken in the same manner by an accommodation— But if he must resort to Governments and Jurisdictions in this case, I could only refer him to the Sovereign of Aury, who he told me was the king of France; or to the Governor of East-Florida, of which Amelia-Island was a part— As to the pretension that the French should be admitted into the Ports of Louisiana, upon a footing different from that of other Nations, I should receive with due consideration any thing that he might think proper to write me on that subject; but our principles were so settled, I did not think any alteration could result from it. He hinted that he could bring a very strong argument to bear against us upon that point, but intimated that if we would be more compliant with regard to the wines, that might reconcile his Government better to the refusal in the other case. I told him that the President, the Secretary of the Treasury, and myself were all in favour of his wish in respect to the diminution of the duties upon French Wines, and he desired me to see and converse with Mr Lowndes, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, concerning it— He also enquired if I had yet any answer from the Governor of Georgia, about the Frenchmen drawn as Militia men, at Savannah— I had not. The Conversation that I had with Mr King, was of a general Nature; upon the state and prospects of our political relations with all the European Powers, particularly Spain and England— He gave me no particular intimation of his own views, upon these Subjects, but I inferred from the tenour of his Conversation, that he did not disapprove the course which the President has determined to pursue. It was near six O’Clock, when I left the Office and came home— On the way I overtook Mr Scott and Mr Pope the Delegates of the Missouri & Illinois Territories. Judge Lucas of the Missouri Territory had called at my Office two days ago, to speak about the re-appointment of judge Stuart one of his Colleagues, whose Commission has expired and was to be renewed. Mr Scott had written to me urging an early nomination, on the 2d. of this Month— The names had been sent to the President at the time, but the nomination was postponed and then forgotten. Scott says the nomination was only sent to the Senate yesterday; and that the Commission will not be received in Season for holding the Court, on the fourth Monday in March— Mrs Boyd spent the Evening here with my wife, who is yet very unwell and confined to her bed— Susan Buchanan was at Mr De Neuville’s where the Comte d’Artois’s birth-day was celebrated— We were invited to dine there— I was occupied the whole Evening in revising and finishing the draft of the Note to Mr Onis.

Day. The distribution is the same, as that of last Month. Still rising about seven in the Morning; and returning to bed about midnight— With the interval of half an hour at Breakfast and an hour at dinner, my whole time is absorbed in the business of my Office; in attendance upon the President concerning it, or in receiving Visitors. Business breeds faster than I can provide for it, and much of it is unavoidably neglected. I see as little of Company at home or abroad as possible, and consequently visitors are still more overlooked than business. I have projects of arranging and methodizing business in a manner which may expedite the transaction of it; but have not at least while Congress is in Session time to reduce the projects themselves into order— Every thing is hurried, and of course, scarcely any thing is done well. But I hope after the Session of Congress closes that there will be occasionally some hours of leisure.
